exercises.exerciseName: Put these sentences from the story in the right order

content.question:
Put these sentences from the story in the right order and write them out in a paragraph. Don’t refer to the text.
1. I shall be so glad when today is over.
2. Having a leg tied up and hopping about on a crutch is almost fun, I guess.
3. I don’t think I’ll mind being deaf for a day — at least not much.
4. But being blind is so frightening.
5. Only you must tell me about things.
6. Let’s go for a little walk.
7. The other bad days can’t be half as bad as this.
Why do you think the writer visited Miss Beam’s school?
What was the ‘game’ that every child in the school had to play?
“Each term every child has one blind day, one lame day…” Complete the line. Which day was the hardest? Why was it the hardest?
What was the purpose of these special days?
Match the words and phrases with their meanings in the box below.
Re-word these lines from the story: I had heard a great deal about Miss Beam’s school.
Re-word these lines from the story: Miss Beam was all that I had expected — middle-aged, full of authority.
Re-word these lines from the story: I went to the window which overlooked a large garden.
Re-word these lines from the story: “We cannot bandage the children’s mouths, so they really have to exercise their will-power.”
Given below is a page from a dictionary. Look at it carefully and find a word which means the same as ghastly. Write down the word and its two meanings.
Given below is a page from a dictionary. Look at it carefully and find a word meaning a part of the school year.
Given below is a page from a dictionary. Look at it carefully and find a word that means examination.
Why does the poet want to know where the teachers go at four o’clock?
What are the things normal people do that the poet talks about?
What does the poet imagine about where teachers live, what they do at home, the people with whom they live, and their activities when they were children in school?
Why does the poet wonder if teachers also do things that other people do?
How does the poet plan to find out? What will he do once he finds out?
What do you think the phrase 'punished in the corner' from the poem means?
What do you think the phrase 'leave their greens' from the poem means?
